Apologies for the incomplete response earlier. Here are the recommended readings for weeks 12-15: | Week | Recommended Readings | | --- | --- | | 12 | - Bardach, E., & Patashnik, E. M. (2016). A practical guide for policy analysis: The eightfold path to more effective problem solving (5th ed.). CQ Press.
- Howlett, M., Ramesh, M., & Perl, A. (2009). Studying public policy: Policy cycles and policy subsystems (3rd ed.). Oxford University Press. | | 13 | - Fischer, F. (2003). Reframing public policy: Discursive politics and deliberative practices. Oxford University Press.
- Hajer, M. A. (1995). The politics of environmental discourse: Ecological modernization and the policy process. Oxford University Press. | | 14 | - Haas, P. M. (1992). Introduction: Epistemic communities and international policy coordination. International organization, 46(1), 1-35.
- Jenkins-Smith, H. C., Nohrstedt, D., Weible, C. M., & Sabatier, P. A. (2014). The advocacy coalition framework: Foundations, evolution, and ongoing research. In Theories of the policy process (pp. 183-224). Westview Press. | | 15 | - Grindle, M. S., & Thomas, J. W. (1989). Public choices and policy change: The political economy of reform in developing countries. Johns Hopkins University Press.
- Andrews, M. (2018). The limits of institutional reform in development: Changing rules for realistic solutions. Cambridge University Press. | Please note that these readings are only recommendations and not a comprehensive list. You may choose to supplement them with additional materials based on your course objectives and teaching style. As for assessing student learning, here are some suggestions for each week: | Week | Assessment | | --- | --- | | 1 | Class discussion on the concept of public policy analysis and its significance in public administration | | 2 | Written reflection on the policy cycle and policy subsystems | | 3 | Case study analysis on the implementation of a public policy | | 4 | Group presentation on program evaluation techniques | | 5 | Critical analysis of a public policy issue using the policy paradox framework | | 6 | Essay on the role of bureaucracy in public policy making | | 7 | Written critique of a bureaucratic accountability mechanism | | 8 | Cost-benefit analysis exercise on a public policy issue | | 9 | Group project on a multi-criteria decision-making problem | | 10 | Research paper on public value and stakeholder participation | | 11 | Written analysis of a policy discourse | | 12 | Policy memo on a public policy problem using the eightfold path | | 13 | Deliberation exercise on an environmental policy issue | | 14 | Advocacy coalition mapping exercise | | 15 | Comparative analysis of institutional reform initiatives in different countries | Again, these are just suggestions and you may choose to use different assessment methods or modify them based on your teaching goals and preferences.
